title: 114_hr451
content: The "Safe and Secure Federal Websites Act of 2015" ensures functionality and security of new federal websites collecting personally identifiable information. The "Safe and Secure Federal Websites Act of 2015" requires agencies to certify to Congress that new Federal PII websites are fully functional and secure before deployment. If certification is not submitted within 90 days of enactment, the website must be made inaccessible to the public. The "Safe and Secure Federal Websites Act of 2015" mandates agencies to certify new Federal PII websites as fully functional and secure before deployment. If certification is not submitted within 90 days, the website must be inaccessible to the public. An exception is made for beta websites in development or testing phases, where public access to PII-related portions requires an agreement acknowledging risks. This section does not apply to websites operated independently by entities like States or localities, regardless of funding. The "Safe and Secure Federal Websites Act of 2015" requires agencies to certify new Federal PII websites as fully functional and secure before deployment. The Act defines terms like "agency," "fully functional," and "new federal personally identifiable information website." The "Safe and Secure Federal Websites Act of 2015" defines terms like "new Federal PII website" as a website operated by an agency, accessible to the public, and collecting personally identifiable information after October 1, 2012. The term "operational" refers to a website that collects and stores personally identifiable information and is accessible to the public. (5) Personally identifiable information (PII) refers to any information about an individual collected by an agency, including details like name, social security number, and biometric records. (6) Responsible agency is the entity in charge of operating a new Federal PII website. The term "secure" for a new Federal PII website means compliance with specific requirements to protect personally identifiable information. This includes capturing information at the latest step in a user input sequence and encrypting or masking data to ensure protection. The responsible agency for the website has made efforts to minimize domain name confusion and requires personnel accessing personally identifiable information to complete a Standard Form 85P and sign a non-disclosure agreement. They also ensure only trustworthy individuals can access this information. The responsible agency must have sufficient personnel to address website issues promptly and monitor security threats. The term "State" includes all states, the District of Columbia, territories, federally recognized Indian tribes. SEC. 3. PRIVACY BREACH REQUIREMENTS. The Privacy breach requirements under the Information Security Amendment mandate agencies to establish policies for handling breaches involving personally identifiable information, including notifying affected individuals within 72 hours and reporting to a designated Federal cybersecurity center. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may require agencies to take specific actions in response to information security breaches, including data breach analysis, fraud resolution services, and credit protection services. Agency heads must ensure compliance with established policies and procedures. The Director must report to Congress annually on agency compliance. The Federal Cybersecurity Center is defined as various entities including the Department of Defense Cyber Crime Center, the Intelligence Community Incident Response Center, and others as determined by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. (b) Technical and Conforming Amendment.--The table of sections for subchapter II of chapter 35 of title 44, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following: Privacy breach requirements are outlined in section 3559.
